Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Development of Anti-fouling Electrochemical Membranes for Water Treatment

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1159764/115/8990
Chaplin/Elabd

This NSF award by the Chemical and Biological Separations program supports work by Professors Brian Chaplin and Yossef Elabd to develop and test reactive electrochemical membranes (REMs) for water treatment applications. The novel REM acts to both filter and destroy contaminants on its service. These self-cleaning properties will allow the REM to have a long operational life without membrane fouling, and have the potential to greatly enhance the application space of membrane technologies. Work will focus on understanding the mechanisms of operation of the REMs at the fundamental level by using advanced characterization techniques. This work seeks to lay the groundwork for a new generation of reactive electrode materials that will have utility in a vast number of applications.

The development of a successful REM would be a monumental step in overcoming the primary downfall of membrane separation systems (Membrane Fouling). The work proposed here has the potential to lay the groundwork for the development of REMs that can operate with minimal fouling which will result in more efficient aqueous separations. Such an accomplishment would radically change the fields of Environmental and Chemical Engineering and has broad applications in water treatment and other fields. Specifically, the proposed research is expected to contribute significantly to two main areas in water treatment: 1) membrane filtration and 2) water disinfection.

The project will also result in the training and development of one graduate and several undergraduate students and will seek to increase participation of students from underrepresented groups in engineering research. The proposed work will also seek to initiate the development of a Villanova-Drexel joint NSF-REU/RET program focused on: Water-Energy Nexus: Sustainable Solutions through Materials, Engineering, and Design. This joint effort will utilize the Universities? focus on undergraduate education and will be the most efficient means of achieving community outreach in the greater Philadelphia area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: The objectives of this collaborative research were to develop a novel reactive electrochemical membrane (REM) that can simultaneously filter and oxidize organic foulants, and to study the mechanisms associated with membrane fouling and mitigation of membrane fouling at the membrane surface. New REMs were fabricated in this study using a unique electrospinning/electrospraying (E/E) technique that produces high porosity, high surface area filtration membranes. These REMs were compared to previous low surface area REMs. Model foulants (biological, particulate, and organics) with key chemical properties were used as probes for elucidating mechanisms associated with membrane fouling and fouling mitigation in both types of membranes. A methodology was developed that integrates traditional membrane fouling experiments, in situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), in situ (FTIR-ATR), and ex situ physical/chemical surface characterization. The combination of techniques constitutes a new methodology for studying a new generation of reactive membrane materials and lead to the development of a mathematical model that can be used to further optimize the system.

 

Intellectual Merit: More specifically, in this project, porous, flexible, REMs for water purification were synthesized by a novel simultaneous E/E technique, which produced a network of poly(sulfone) fibers and Ti4O7 particles as evidenced by scanning electron microscopy. Cyclic voltammetry indicated that the kinetics for water electrolysis reactions and the Fe(CN)64-/3- redox couple were enhanced by Ti4O7 deposition using the E/E technique. Membrane filtration experiments using phenol as a model contaminant showed a 2.6-fold enhancement in the observed first-order rate constant for phenol oxidation in filtration mode relative to cross-flow operation. Phenol oxidation in filtration mode was approaching the pore diffusion mass transfer limit, and was 6 to 8 times higher than measured in a previous study that utilized a conventional ceramic Ti4O7 REM operated in filtration mode and is comparable to rate constants obtained with carbon nanotube flow-through reactors, which are among the highest reported in the literature to date. These new E/E REMs represent a transformation in the field of water filtration membranes and provide a new platform to investigate electrochemical water filtration.

 

Broader Impacts: In this work, the development of a new generation water filtration membrane (E/E REM) with high flux, high rejection, and minimal fouling was accomplished. This new type of reactive membrane has the potential to radically change the fields of Environmental and Chemical Engineering and has broad applications in water treatment and aligned electrochemical processes, such as electrolysis (hydrogen production), flow batteries (large-scale energy storage), electrodialysis (desalination of water), and reverse electrodialysis (ocean/blue energy). This research contributed significantly to two main areas in water treatment: 1) membrane filtration and 2) water disinfection. One female graduate student was trained with the NSF funds and the research results from this project were disseminated to the broader scientific community through publication in the AIChE Journal and a presentation at the national AIChE conference.
